questions.text: A 61-year-old farmer comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressively worsening cough and shortness of breath. He has had a 7.5-kg (16.5-lb) weight loss during this period. He smokes occasionally and does not drink alcohol. Physical examination shows clubbing of the fingers. End-inspiratory crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral reticulonodular densities with interstitial fibrosis. Microscopic examination of a lung biopsy specimen shows noncaseating granulomas in the interstitium. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activation of the immune system by Aspergillus is seen in all forms of aspergillosis. ABPA resembles asthma clinically, and could also cause dyspnea and cough, as seen in this patient. X-rays of patients with aspergillosis are often characterized by parenchymal opacities (ABPA) or nodules (chronic pulmonary aspergillosis). However, aspergillosis is more commonly seen in patients who are immunocompromised or have underlying lung disease (unlikely given this patient's history) and is not typically associated with granuloma formation.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (left: PA view; right: right lateral decubitus view)

A solid ovoid mass (red overlay) in the dependent portion of a large right upper lobe cavity (blue outlines) seen on the PA radiograph moves to a dependent position on a subsequent right lateral decubitus radiograph.

Saprophytic (noninvasive) aspergillus develops in the form of aspergilloma (also called a fungus ball or mycetoma) in preexisting cavities, such as those resulting from tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. Surrounding air has a crescentic appearance (Monod sign; green overlay). Movement to a dependent location with a change in patient position supports the diagnosis of aspergilloma.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic inhalation of silica generates oxygen free radicals that induce inflammation and activation of alveolar macrophages. Over time, this can lead to fibrosis, which has a very similar appearance on x-ray to what is seen in this patient. However, silicosis is not a granulomatous disease and is more commonly seen in workers involved in sandblasting, mining, or glass production rather than farmers.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of exposure to silica dust

Numerous bilateral small nodular opacities (examples indicated by green overlay) < 10 mm diameter are seen in all lobes but show an upper zonal predominant distribution.

Nodules in simple (uncomplicated) silicosis can be diffusely distributed; however, they often predominate in the upper zones of the lungs, particularly in the superior and posterior portions of the upper lobes and superior segments of the lower lobes.

C) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is characterized by a granulomatous interstitial pulmonary disease and is most commonly observed in patients with prolonged exposure to specific disease-precipitating antigens, such as the fungal spores and thermophilic actinomycetes found in moldy hay. This exposure induces a mixed type III hypersensitivity/type IV hypersensitivity reaction that manifests with IgG antibody-antigen complex deposition in the lung parenchyma and vessel walls and subsequent granulomatous inflammation.
Image Description:

H&E stain: There is a circumscribed granuloma (green area) of lymphocytes and multinucleated giant cells (red areas) on the left below the bronchus (Br), which are a characteristic indication of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. (Alv = alveolus, B = blood vessel)

D) INCORRECT:

IgE-mediated histamine release is a defining feature of atopic conditions such as allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis, and asthma. Like this patient, patients with asthma may present with worsening cough and shortness of breath. However, asthma does not cause digital clubbing, pulmonary fibrosis, or noncaseating granulomas.

E) INCORRECT:

Excessive elastase activity causes the parenchymal destruction and loss of elastic recoil characteristically seen in α1-antitrypsin deficiency. Like this patient, α1-antitrypsin deficiency can also present with a chronic cough and worsening shortness of breath. However, expected x-ray findings would include lung hyperinflation and increased lucency, rather than the fibrotic changes seen here.
questions.hint: This patient has an occupational disease associated with frequent exposure to birds, hay, or reactive chemical species.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman reports a 6-month history of fevers, fatigue, a nonproductive cough, and dyspnea. Her symptoms improved during a recent trip to Europe, but since returning home one month ago, her symptoms have returned and worsened. She has no family or personal history of lung disease and has never smoked cigarettes. She works as a corporate lawyer. The only pets at home are a bird and freshwater fish.
On physical examination, the patient is uncomfortable and tachypneic. She is afebrile with a blood pressure of 125/70 mm Hg, a heart rate of 98 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 85% while she is breathing ambient air. Examination of the head and neck reveals no sinus tenderness and normal oropharynx mucosa. She has bilateral crackles. Cardiac examination is normal.
CT of the chest is obtained (figure).
Pulmonary function test results are notable for decreases in both FVC and FEV1 ; the FEV1 /FVC ratio is 88%. There is no significant bronchodilator response. Diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide is 56% of predicted.
Bronchoscopy is performed, and bronchoalveolar lavage is notable for 40% lymphocytes. Transbronchial biopsies demonstrate findings of lymphocytic infiltration and loosely formed granulomas.
Following initial stabilization with supplemental oxygen and oral prednisone, which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for treating this patient’s lung disease?

choices.text: Recommend removal of the bird from the home
Recommend removal of the fish from the home
Initiate albuterol and an inhaled glucocorticoid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-term glucocorticoid therapy should be avoided, and glucocorticoid-sparing immunosuppressive agents such as methotrexate and azathioprine are not indicated for bird-fancier’s lung.

B) CORRECT:

The findings of lymphocyte predominance in bronchoalveolar fluid and granulomas on transbronchial biopsies are most consistent with hypersensitivity pneumonitis. The most appropriate management strategy in a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis is to remove the patient from ongoing exposure to potential antigens. Birds are a well-recognized cause of hypersensitivity pneumonitis; the syndrome is sometimes called bird-fancier’s lung.

Chest CT in patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis most typically reveals bilateral upper-lobe predominant ground-glass opacities, centrilobular nodules, and mosaic attenuation.

Although removal of the source of hypersensitivity is the most important intervention, patients with severe symptoms may benefit from an initial short course of a systemic glucocorticoid.

Key learning point: Following initial stabilization, the most appropriate management strategy for a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis is to minimize antigen exposure.

C) INCORRECT:

Fish are not a recognized cause of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Long-term glucocorticoid therapy should be avoided, and glucocorticoid-sparing immunosuppressive agents such as methotrexate and azathioprine are not indicated for bird-fancier’s lung.

E) INCORRECT:

The patient's clinical picture is inconsistent with asthma, and she does not have airflow obstruction responsive to bronchodilators, so treatment with inhaled albuterol and inhaled glucocorticoids is not appropriate.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man who has worked on a farm since childhood and never smoked reports a 3-month history of progressive nonproductive cough, shortness of breath, and episodic fevers.
Current pulmonary diagnostic evaluation is notable for abnormal results on pulmonary function testing, with moderate airflow limitation and decreased diffusion capacity. His chest CT scan demonstrates bilateral upper-lobe-predominant centrilobular nodules and ground-glass opacities with mild air trapping. His serum immunoglobulin E level is within normal limits.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is associated with an elevated immunoglobulin E level and central bronchiectasis seen on imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Coxsackie virus infection is associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease as well as other illnesses that are not consistent with this patient's presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

Asthma (including occupational asthma) is not associated with decreased diffusion capacity on pulmonary function testing or with ground-glass opacities on CT imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis is not typically associated with abnormal diffusion capacity and ground-glass opacities.

E) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a granulomatous inflammatory lung disease associated with a variety of organic antigen exposures. Common antigens include moldy hay or grain in farm work but can also include mold in water-damaged areas in a residential home. Other exposures include birds, hot tub or sauna use (particularly when indoors because of reentrainment of air with antigens), and mold released from lumber stripping and processing. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically manifests with cough and dyspnea related to antigen exposure. Typical findings on high-resolution CT of the chest include upper- and middle-lobe-predominant ground-glass opacities, poorly defined centrilobular nodules, mosaic attenuation, and air trapping.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a farmer who develops dyspnea, moderate airflow limitation, abnormal diffusion capacity, and bilateral ground-glass opacities is hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman is referred for evaluation of a nagging, nonproductive cough and an abnormal chest radiograph (figure). She says that the cough started 1 to 2 years ago but has worsened during the past 6 months, has become associated with dyspnea on exertion, and is limiting her ability to continue her job as a tour guide. She also reports an unintended weight loss of 11 kg during the past 5 months. She states that she does not experience fevers, chills, or hemoptysis and that she does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Until recently, she had numerous birds, including parakeets, in her home.
Physical examination reveals tachypnea and crackles at the bases of both lungs. Her oxygen saturation is 87% while she is breathing ambient air and drops to 82% with ambulation. A bronchoalveolar lavage reveals 70% lymphocytes. Pulmonary function testing reveals mild restriction with a moderately reduced diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide.
Removing the birds from the patient’s home has minimally improved her cough, but her dyspnea and desaturation with ambulation persist.
In addition to supplemental oxygen, which one of the following pharmacologic treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although infliximab and azathioprine are used to treat autoimmune diseases, they are not first-line therapy for hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate is not itself a therapy for hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Indirect evidence supports the use of N-acetylcysteine in patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis, but it is not a first-line therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although infliximab and azathioprine are used to treat autoimmune diseases, they are not first-line therapy for hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

E) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an interstitial lung condition characterized by inflammation in response to the inhalation of organic antigens to which the patient has been previously sensitized. Bronchoalveolar lavage frequently reveals a lymphocytic predominance but is not a sensitive diagnostic test. Chest imaging can reveal evidence of fibrosis.

Birds are a well-recognized cause of hypersensitivity pneumonitis; the syndrome is sometimes called bird-fancier’s lung. The most important intervention is to remove the offending exposure. For patients with symptomatic, progressive disease and a reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) or a reduced diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO), initial therapy includes prednisone 0.5 mg per kilogram of ideal body weight to a maximum of 30 mg daily for 4 to 6 weeks followed by a slow taper.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial pharmacologic therapy for a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis is to reduce antigen exposure; if symptoms are persistent and there is a reduction of either forced vital capacity or diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide, then treatment with a systemic glucocorticoid should be initiated.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a 10-pack-year history of cigarette smoking reports dyspnea and a nonproductive cough that have progressed during the past 8 months, starting soon after his apartment flooded. The dyspnea occurs after walking two blocks or up one flight of stairs; he previously had no limitations. He has no pets.
Physical examination reveals scattered bilateral crackles but is otherwise unremarkable. CT of the chest shows diffuse centrilobular nodules and air trapping. Pulmonary function testing documents a reduced FEV1 /FVC ratio of 60%.
Which one of the following evaluations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Trial of living away from the residence

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skin testing in patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis is impractical, as the few available antigens are nonspecific and poorly standardized.

B) INCORRECT:

A methacholine challenge test is appropriate for confirming a diagnosis of asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

For many patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis, the causative antigen is never identified. Air sampling can be considered if the index of suspicion for mold is high, but mold is often difficult to locate, and standards for what is an acceptable, tolerable, or normal quantity of it are not well established.

D) CORRECT:

Diagnosing hypersensitivity pneumonitis relies on a high index of suspicion and a thorough patient history. Avoidance of the suspected causative antigen may improve symptoms (unless fibrosis has occurred) and may therefore provide additional circumstantial evidence of the cause of symptoms. Antigen avoidance is also the most effective treatment for acute and subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis. A course of glucocorticoids may be considered if symptoms are severe.

Key learning point: The best initial evaluation for a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a trial of avoiding the suspected causative antigen.

E) INCORRECT:

If the patient does not improve with avoidance of the presumed provocative antigen, the next steps would include serum precipitins testing and bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage or transbronchial biopsies. Only if those studies were unrevealing would a video-assisted lung biopsy be pursued.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man reports a 6-month history of increasing cough, dyspnea, anorexia, and weight loss. He has no prior history of respiratory disease or recurrent infections.
He lives with his wife and their two pet birds, which they have owned for approximately one year. He works as an accountant and has been in the same office for 3 years. He has had no recent travel.
Chest CT reveals scattered ground-glass opacities.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to establish a diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Measure specific immunoglobulin E antibodies against potential antigens
Measure the lymphocyte population in a bronchoalveolar lavage specimen
Measure total serum immunoglobulin E and other immunoglobulins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies are found in a variety of pulmonary diseases including granulomatosis with polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome) but not hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Blood tests are of limited utility. Leukocytosis, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and increased levels of quantitative immunoglobulins and C-reactive protein are observed in many patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Measuring specific IgE antibodies against potential antigens may play a role in certain situations to evaluate for IgE-mediated allergies to environmental antigens, but it is not helpful in the evaluation of suspected hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s progressive dyspnea with systemic symptoms in the setting of prolonged exposure to bird antigens is consistent with hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Respiratory findings (such as cough, dyspnea, crackles, or wheezing on examination) and systemic findings (such as febrile episodes, fatigue, and weight loss) that appear — or that worsen — hours after an antigen exposure support the diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

Bronchoalveolar lavage is helpful in establishing a diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. A marked bronchoalveolar lavage lymphocytosis (> 20%) is nonspecific but consistent with the diagnosis. An elevation in the number of CD8+ T cells and a CD4+-to-CD8+ ratio < 1.0 is suggestive of the diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis in a patient who has a clear history of an appropriate exposure and typical clinical and radiographic findings (reticular, nodular, or ground-glass opacities). In patients without a classic presentation, transbronchial lung biopsies that demonstrate loosely formed granulomas help with diagnostic certainty.

Key learning point: In patients with suspected hypersensitivity pneumonitis, the diagnosis can be established by finding a CD4+-to-CD8+ ratio of < 1 in a sample of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid.
Image Description:

CT chest (inspiratory phase; axial plane; lung window) of a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP)

An irregular reticular pattern of fibrosis predominates in the subpleural regions of the mid zones of the lungs. A small amount of honeycombing (example indicated by red overlay) is seen. There is a heterogeneous pattern of lung attenuation (mosaic attenuation), with areas of low attenuation (examples indicated by green overlays) in some regions with no fibrosis; expiratory phase imaging could help assess whether or not such areas represent air trapping.

Fibrotic HP has a variable appearance on CT. A pattern typical of fibrotic HP shows a random axial distribution of coarse reticulation and small airway disease with minimal honeycombing and no zonal predominance. Subpleural fibrosis can be compatible with HP, as can upper zonal, lower zonal, or central predominant distributions.

E) INCORRECT:

Blood tests are of limited utility. Leukocytosis, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and increased levels of quantitative immunoglobulins and C-reactive protein are observed in many patients.

Measuring total immunoglobulin E (IgE) levels may be helpful in allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, but it is not useful in making a diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman is seen for a 2-month history of worsening symptoms of cough, fever, malaise, headache, and dyspnea during a particularly warm and rainy summer. She works in dairy farming and reports that the symptoms occur daily, roughly 8 hours after she feeds the cows in the barn. She has also noted a 5-kg weight loss during this illness. She has no significant medical history, does not smoke, and takes a multivitamin and calcium daily. She has had no ill contacts.
On examination, she has bilateral crackles on lung auscultation. A chest radiograph is normal.
Which one of the following conditions is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with underlying lung disease or immunocompromised states, Mycobacterium avium complex is a pathologic infectious organism; however, in immunocompetent patients, it can cause hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Patients with hypersensitivity to Mycobacterium avium complex often have a history of hot-tub exposure, which results in a hypersensitivity pneumonitis referred to as hot-tub lung. This patient had no reported history of hot-tub use.

B) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis occurs in patients with cystic fibrosis and asthma after the bronchi become colonized by Aspergillus species. The clinical presentation can be dominated by symptoms of asthma but can also include cough, dyspnea, expectoration of brown mucus plugs, and malaise; repeated episodes of inflammation and bronchial obstruction can lead to bronchiectasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Cattle allergy is not associated with fever and would manifest with rhinoconjunctivitis, asthma, or both.

D) INCORRECT:

Ragweed-induced asthma is not associated with fever and would occur in the fall only.

E) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is diagnosed based on a constellation of respiratory and often constitutional symptoms of cough, wheezing, dyspnea, weight loss, fever, fatigue, and malaise and signs of crackles on lung examination. Symptoms typically occur 4 to 8 hours after antigen exposure. Chest radiographs can show reticulonodular or patchy opacities, although they can also appear normal.

Many antigens can cause hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Thermophilic actinomycetes are a common cause in farmers who are exposed to moldy hay; thus, this form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis is known as farmer’s lung. Farmer's lung is more common in nonsmokers than in smokers.

Key learning point: Cough, fever, malaise, headache, and dyspnea accompanied by pulmonary crackles that develop in a cattle farmer is most consistent with the diagnosis of farmer’s lung, a form of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with fever, chills, and dyspnea that started 6 hours after she helped remodel a basement that had extensive water damage from a flood. Her medical history is notable only for occasional wheezing episodes during childhood that were treated with inhalers, but she recalls no episodes during the past 20 years.
Her temperature is 38.2°C, and fine crackles are audible in both lung bases. There are no other remarkable findings.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph reveals diffuse bilateral alveolar opacities in both lung fields.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is characterized by repeated bouts of wheezing, central bronchiectasis on chest radiograph, and evidence of immune reactivity to aspergillus. This condition would not be expected to occur acutely after exposure to mold.

B) INCORRECT:

Allergen-associated exacerbation of asthma would not cause fever, crackles on auscultation, or the findings on the chest radiograph.

C) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis can occur after occupational exposures or after exposure to any number of antigens that originate from bacteria, fungi, mycobacteria, amoebas, animal excreta or urine, chemicals, and medications. This patient was presumably exposed to mold (fungi) in her basement. In the acute form, symptoms are often delayed until 4 to 8 hours after exposure and include fever, chills, and dyspnea.

The findings of bilateral nodular opacities (that represent underlying alveolitis) on the chest radiograph and the temporal association with exposure to a flooded basement argue against actinomycosis.

Key learning point: The development of fever, chills, and dyspnea within 4 to 8 hours of likely mold exposure and accompanied by bilateral nodular opacities that represent underlying alveolitis is most consistent with a diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary nocardiosis tends to occur in immunosuppressed individuals, and symptoms are more gradual in onset than those in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

The findings of bilateral nodular opacities (that represent underlying alveolitis) on the chest radiograph and the temporal association with exposure to a flooded basement argue against actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis tends to occur in immunosuppressed individuals, and symptoms are more gradual in onset than those in this case.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl presents with fever, chills, and dyspnea that started 6 hours after she was playing in a basement that had extensive water damage from a flood. Her medical history is notable only for wheezing with upper respiratory infections in early childhood. She has had no episodes of wheezing or respiratory symptoms during the past 8 years.
Her temperature is 38.2°C, and fine crackles are audible in both lung bases. There are no other remarkable findings.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph reveals diffuse bilateral alveolar opacities in both lung fields.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary nocardiosis and actinomycosis tend to occur in immunosuppressed individuals, and symptoms are more gradual in onset than those in this case.

B) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis can occur after occupational exposures or exposure to a number of organic substances including molds and birds. This patient was presumably exposed to mold in her basement. In the acute form, symptoms often are delayed until 4 to 8 hours after exposure and include fever, chills, and dyspnea.

Key learning point: Fever, chills, and dyspnea accompanied by bilateral alveolar opacities on a chest radiograph that develop within 4 to 8 hours of playing in a previously flooded basement is most consistent with a diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Allergen-associated exacerbation of asthma would not cause fever, crackles on auscultation, or the findings on the chest radiograph.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is characterized by repeated bouts of wheezing, central bronchiectasis on chest radiograph, and evidence of immune reactivity to aspergillus. This condition would not be expected to occur acutely after exposure to mold.

E) INCORRECT:

The findings of bilateral alveolar opacities on the chest radiograph and the temporal association with exposure to a flooded basement argue against actinomycosis.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 43 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I'm worried about this cough lasting for so long.”
History of Present Illness:

9-month history of progressively worsening cough

sodium chloride inhalation and air humidification has not improved symptoms
increasingly short of breath with mild exercise; needs to take several breaks when cleaning out the horse stable

Past Medical History:


4 episodes of urinary tract infections over the past 12 months; treated with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole and fosfomycin
atopic dermatitis that is well controlled with moisturizing agents

Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory 
Psychosocial History:

lives with husband and daughter

started a new job as a groom in a horse stable 1 year ago
previously worked as a gardener
has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years

does not drink alcoholic beverages or use other substances

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.6°C(97.9°F)
96/min
20/min
110/70 mm Hg
96% on RA
168 cm(5 ft 6 in)
56 kg(124 lb)
19.8 kg/m2




Appearance: sitting in chair; not in acute distress
Skin: no rashes
HEENT: normal conjunctivae and oropharynx; PERRLA; thyroid gland is normal in size with no mass or tenderness
Pulmonary: bilateral diffuse crackles

Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender
Extremities: no edemas; no digital clubbing 
Neurologic: fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits

Diagnostic Studies

pulmonary function testing: FEV1 76% of predicted; FVC 74% of predicted; FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.95; DLCO decreased

chest x-ray: diffuse increase in reticular opacities



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is associated with a history of smoking and may manifest with dyspnea, chronic cough, and decreased DLCO. However, PFTs would reveal an obstructive lung disease pattern with a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, while chest x-rays usually show signs of pulmonary hyperinflation rather than fibrotic changes.

B) INCORRECT:

Medication-induced lung injury may manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, PFTs showing a restrictive pattern with decreased DLCO, and fibrotic changes on chest x-ray. Several medications potentially induce lung injury, including nitrofurantoin, amiodarone, and certain chemotherapeutic agents such as bleomycin, busulfan, and methotrexate. Medication-induced lung injury is not an adverse effect of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole and fosfomycin.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis can be caused by hay containing Aspergillus spores and may manifest with chronic cough, shortness of breath, and fibrotic changes on chest x-ray. However, it primarily affects immunocompromised individuals and individuals with previous pulmonary pathologies such as tuberculosis. Symptoms frequently include hemoptysis and recurrent acute pneumonia due to superinfections. Chest x-rays commonly show cavities or aspergillomas adjacent to areas of fibrosis.

D) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) is a combined type III and type IV hypersensitivity reaction caused by inhalation of organic particles, such as animal proteins, microorganisms (e.g., actinomycete spores from moldy hay), and inorganic chemicals (see “Overview of antigens and diseases in hypersensitivity pneumonitis” table). HP is often a result of occupational exposure to these antigens and is a notifiable occupational disease. HP can be acute, manifesting within 12 hours of exposure with flu-like symptoms, dyspnea, and chest tightness; or chronic, manifesting after weeks to years of exposure with progressive dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss. The diagnosis of HP is based on a history of antigen exposure, typical clinical and radiological features, and supportive diagnostic studies. PFTs typically show findings of ILD.

A high-resolution CT should be obtained in all patients to classify HP as fibrotic or nonfibrotic, which impacts further workup, treatment, and prognosis. The cornerstone of HP management is antigen avoidance.

E) INCORRECT:

Allergic asthma is triggered by allergens such as mold spores, which may be found in hay. It is also associated with atopic dermatitis and typically manifests with cough and dyspnea. However, PFTs in allergic asthma show obstructive lung disease pattern with a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio and normal or increased DLCO. Imaging is not routinely recommended for allergic asthma, but chest x-rays are usually normal or may show pulmonary hyperinflation and bronchial wall thickening. Additionally, physical examination is likely to reveal end-expiratory wheezes rather than diffuse crackles.
questions.hint: This patient's restrictive lung disease pattern with decreased DLCO in pulmonary function testing (PFTs) and chest x-ray findings are consistent with interstitial lung disease (ILD). A detailed exposure history is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who has worked on a farm since childhood and never smoked reports a 3-month history of progressive nonproductive cough, shortness of breath, and episodic fevers. Current pulmonary diagnostic evaluation is notable for abnormal results on pulmonary function testing, with moderate airflow limitation and decreased diffusion capacity. His chest CT scan demonstrates bilateral upper-lobe-predominant centrilobular nodules and ground-glass opacities with mild air trapping. His serum immunoglobulin E level is within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is associated with an elevated immunoglobulin E level and central bronchiectasis seen on imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Coxsackie virus infection is associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease as well as other illnesses that are not consistent with this patient's presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

Asthma (including occupational asthma) is not associated with decreased diffusion capacity on pulmonary function testing or with ground-glass opacities on CT imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis is not typically associated with abnormal diffusion capacity and ground-glass opacities.

E) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a granulomatous inflammatory lung disease associated with a variety of organic antigen exposures. Common antigens include moldy hay or grain in farm work but can also include mold in water-damaged areas in a residential home. Other exposures include birds, hot tub or sauna use (particularly when indoors because of reentrainment of air with antigens), and mold released from lumber stripping and processing. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically manifests with cough and dyspnea related to antigen exposure. Typical findings on high-resolution CT of the chest include upper- and middle-lobe-predominant ground-glass opacities, poorly defined centrilobular nodules, mosaic attenuation, and air trapping.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a farmer who develops dyspnea, moderate airflow limitation, abnormal diffusion capacity, and bilateral ground-glass opacities is hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man who has worked on a farm since childhood and has never smoked comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of progressive nonproductive cough, shortness of breath, and episodic fevers. Pulmonary function testing shows moderate airflow limitation and decreased diffusion capacity. Chest CT scan reveals bilateral upper-lobe-predominant centrilobular nodules and ground-glass opacities with mild air trapping. His serum immunoglobulin E level is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coxsackie virus infection is associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease as well as other illnesses that are not consistent with this patient's presentation.

B) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis is a granulomatous inflammatory lung disease associated with a variety of organic antigen exposures. Common antigens include moldy hay or grain in farm work but can also include mold in water-damaged areas in a residential home. Other exposures include birds, hot tub or sauna use (particularly when indoors because of reentrainment of air with antigens), and mold released from lumber stripping and processing. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically manifests with cough and dyspnea related to antigen exposure. Typical findings on high-resolution CT of the chest include upper- and middle-lobe-predominant ground-glass opacities, poorly defined centrilobular nodules, mosaic attenuation, and air trapping.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a farmer who develops dyspnea, moderate airflow limitation, abnormal diffusion capacity, and bilateral ground-glass opacities is hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is associated with an elevated immunoglobulin E level and central bronchiectasis seen on imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Asthma (including occupational asthma) is not associated with decreased diffusion capacity on pulmonary function testing or with ground-glass opacities on CT imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis is not typically associated with abnormal diffusion capacity and ground-glass opacities.
